Report and Recommendation of the President 
to the Board of Directors
 
 
Project Number: 41243-024 
Loan Number: 3802-MON 
June 2019 
 
 
Proposed Loan for Additional Financing 
Mongolia: Fourth Health Sector Development Project 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Distribution of this document is restricted until it has been approved by the Board of Directors. 
Following such approval, ADB will disclose the document to the public in accordance with 
ADB’s Access to Information Policy.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
Mongolia for the additional financing of the Fourth Health Sector Development Project.  
 
  The additional financing will address cost overruns to complete the Songinohairkhan 
district hospital (SDH)—a new demonstration general hospital in Songinohairkhan, a poor and 
underserved district in the capital city, Ulaanbaatar. 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) approved the Fourth Health Sector Development 
Project on 29 November 2010, to be financed by a $14.00 million Asian Development Fund grant, 
$0.45 million in parallel cofinancing from the World Health Organization, and a $3.70 million 
contribution from the Government of Mongolia.1 The project consists of three components to 
strengthen (i) hospital services in Ulaanbaatar, (ii) human resources development, and (iii) drug 
safety. The grant closing date is 31 December 2020. 
 
  In March 2012, the government requested additional financing to establish the new SDH 
instead of renovating the existing district hospital under component 1 of the grant. ADB approved 
the additional financing on 5 November 2012, comprising a concessional loan of $25.00 million 
from ADB’s ordinary capital resources (OCR) and a government contribution of $2.00 million.2 
The loan closing date is 31 December 2020. The loan consists of the same components as the 
grant. 
 
  In November 2018, the government requested a second additional financing of $16.00 
million to complete the SDH under component 1. The project faces cost overruns caused by (i) 
new government regulations introduced during the implementation of the current project, such as 
new  requirements  for  seismic  resistance  and  upgraded  national  standards  for  hospital 
construction;  (ii)  limited  restructuring  of  the  building  to  address  requests  made  by  nearby 
residents; (iii) the construction of a separate building to house the hospital electrical substation 
and medical gas container, which were originally planned to be located in the basement of the 
hospital, to conform with the requirement of the government inspection authority; (iv) variations in 
the bill of quantities because of omitted works and changes to the quantities of works included in 
the contract; and (v) additional costs to reroute the hospital access road because of the decision 
of the government to retain the existing hospital.3 The decision to retain the existing hospital was 
made in 2018 to address acute shortages of long-term services for chronic conditions, including 
palliative care and rehabilitation services. Rerouting of the hospital access road requires resettling 
a small number of households to ensure access for patients, emergency services, and hospital 
suppliers; and provide parking space for visitors. The proposed additional financing does not 
involve any scale-up of or modification to the current design of the SDH. 
 
  Current project performance. The current project is performing well as it meets all 
criteria: (i) the delivery of the expected outputs is rated successful (component 1 is completed 
                                                
1  ADB. 2010. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Grant to Mongolia for 
the Fourth Health Sector Development Project. Manila. 
2  ADB. 2012. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Proposed Loan for Additional 
Financing to Mongolia for the Fourth Health Sector Development Project. Manila. 
3  Reasons and Estimations of Cost Overruns (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

2 
except for the construction of the SDH, component 2 is 98% completed, and component 3 was 
completed in 2015);4 (ii) the project is rated on track under the project performance system;5 
(iii) the  review  of  safeguards  compliance  confirmed  that  the  project  has  no  fiduciary  and 
safeguards policy compliance issues and that each safeguard covenant item is being complied 
with;6 and (iv) the management of risks is rated successful as all risks included in the risk 
assessment and risk management plan have been managed successfully. As of May 2019, the 
overall progress in establishing the SDH is estimated at 66% and construction is planned to be 
completed in January 2020.7 Of the total $42.83 million, $30.75 million has been contracted and 
$24.09 million has been disbursed: $5.60 million from the ADB grant, $17.58 million from the 
concessional OCR loan, $0.46 million from government contributions, and $0.45 million from the 
World Health Organization. The uncommitted $5.00 million from the ADB grant and $2.81 million 
from government are planned for procurement of medical equipment, information communication 
technology and furniture for the SDH upon completion of construction works. 
 
  Eligibility criteria for additional financing. The additional financing is considered to 
meet the four eligibility criteria for additional financing.8 First, ADB reviewed the current project in 
December 2018 and confirmed its satisfactory performance and that no significant changes in 
approaches and methodologies were envisioned (footnote 4). Accordingly, the current project 
remains technically feasible, economically viable, and financially sound. Second, the government 
accords high priority to the current project given its role in providing critical health services in an 
underserved and densely populated district of Ulaanbaatar. The SDH represents a concrete step 
toward the implementation of the amended Health Law, 2011 by providing a broader range of 
services in district hospitals.9 It will also serve as a model to be replicated in other districts of 
Ulaanbaatar.10 Third, the project outcome, outputs, and project scope of the overall project remain 
unchanged and consistent with the project’s development objectives. Fourth, the overall project 
is  consistent  with  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy,  2017–2020  for  Mongolia,  which 
emphasizes social development through the efficient delivery of health services.11 
 
  Relevance of the additional financing. Additional financing is the most appropriate 
modality to fund the cost overruns to complete the SDH in the most efficient way. Through this 
approach,  current  effective  implementation  arrangements—such  as  the  project  steering 
committee, executing and implementing agencies, the project implementation unit (PIU), and the 
civil works contractor and supervisor—will be maintained to ensure a high degree of readiness 
for the implementation of the additional financing. Completion of the SDH—including the new 
regulatory and quality standards—reinforces its demonstration effect, establishing a new standard 
for modern hospitals in Mongolia in accordance with the State Policy on Health, 2017–2026.12 
The benefits of completing the current project clearly outweigh any consideration of scaling down 
                                                
4  ADB (East Asia Department). 2018. Review Mission Aide Memoire for G0236/L2932-MON: Fourth Health Sector 
Development Project. Aide-mémoire. 12 December (internal). 
5  eOperations Project Performance (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
6  eOperations Status of Safeguards Project Covenants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
7  Revised Time Schedule for the Construction of the Songinohairkhan District Hospital, 2017–2020 (accessible from 
the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
8  ADB. 2018. Operations Manual. OM H5. Manila. (para. 4). 
9  Article 16.12 of the amended law states that general hospitals will provide the population with health care and 
services in no less than seven areas (internal medicine, pediatrics, obstetrics, general surgery, dental care, 
neurology, and infectious diseases) through ambulatory-based and inpatient treatment and care. General hospitals 
may have a decentralized outpatient facility based on the location and health needs of the population. 
10 Innovation and Knowledge Sharing (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
11 ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: Mongolia, 2017–2020—Sustaining Inclusive Growth in a Period of 
Economic Difficulty. Manila. 
12 Government of Mongolia. 2017. The State Policy on Health, 2017–2026. Ulaanbaatar.

3 
or canceling the project. Scaling down the hospital would result in an incomplete model hospital 
whose services do not meet the requirement of the amended Health Law (footnote 9). Canceling 
the current project is not an option as it would result in an 80% completed hospital structure with 
no health services provided in an underserved district of Ulaanbaatar. 
 
  Strategic fit. The additional financing and the current project are in line with the State 
Policy on Health, 2017–2026 objective to improve the accessibility and quality of hospital services; 
ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy,  2017–2020  for  Mongolia  (footnote  11);  and  ADB’s 
Operational Plan for Health, 2015–2020.13 The overall project is also aligned with the ADB 
Strategy 2030 goal of addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities by locating the SDH 
in a high poverty area in Ulaanbaatar, strengthening governance and institutional capacity through 
health management improvement, accelerating progress in gender equality by improving health 
services for women, and constructing a hospital with improved disaster resilience.14 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
  The impact and the outcome of the overall project remain unchanged. The overall project 
is aligned with the following impact: health status of the Mongolian population, including the poor, 
improved (footnote 12). The overall project will have the following outcome: improved health 
sector efficiency, governance, and drug safety implemented nationwide.15 
 
C.  Outputs 
 
  The 12 outputs of the overall project remain unchanged, and the additional financing will 
help complete the construction of the SDH under output 3. The time frame of two indicators under 
outputs 3 and 4 has been adjusted to reflect the revised completion years of the SDH and the 
public reporting system on hospital performance. All other outputs of the overall project have been 
completed. 
 
  The outputs of the overall project are grouped under three components: 
(i)  Component 1: Strengthened hospital services in Ulaanbaatar. The overall 
project has assisted the government in preparing a hospital development policy 
and strategic plan for Ulaanbaatar (output 1), operationalized a hospital capital 
planning  system  (output  2),  and  improved  the  hospital  governance  system 
(output 4). The additional financing will assist in completing the development of a 
demonstration multifunction general hospital in Songinohairkhan (output 3). 
(ii)  Component  2:  Strengthened  human  resources  development.  The  overall 
project  has  strengthened  the  postgraduate  specialist  structure  and  residency 
training (output 5) and integrated a hospital management module in a training 
institution (output 6). 
(iii)  Component  3:  Strengthened  drug  safety  regime.  The  overall  project  has 
established a drug regulatory authority (output 7),16 strengthened drug regulatory 
functions  (output  8),  upgraded  the  drug  control  laboratory  to  international 
standards (output 9), upgraded the standards of good manufacturing processes 
                                                
13 ADB. 2015. Health in Asia and the Pacific: A Focused Approach to Address the Health Needs of ADB Developing 
Member Countries—Operational Plan for Health, 2015–2020. Manila. 
14 ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
15 The revised design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
16 The current project assisted in the establishment of a drug regulatory unit, which will be upgraded to a drug regulatory 
authority after the expected passage of the medicines law in 2019.

4 
for drugs (output 10), strengthened drug post-marketing surveillance and adverse 
drug reaction (output 11), and improved drug safety governance functions of the 
Ministry of Health (MOH) (output 12). 
 
D.  Investment and Financing Plans 
 
  The  additional  financing  is  estimated  to  cost  $16.16  million.  The  overall  project  is 
estimated to cost $58.99 million, including physical and price contingencies, and taxes and duties 
of $4.80 million (Table 1). Detailed cost estimates by expenditure category and by financier are 
included in the project administration manual (PAM).17

Source: ADB estimates. 
 
  The government has requested a regular loan of $16.00 million from ADB’s OCR to help 
finance the project. The loan will have a 25-year term, including a grace period of 8 years; an 
annual interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-
based lending facility; a commitment charge of 0.15% per year (the interest and other charges 
incurred during construction to be capitalized in the loan); and such other terms and conditions 
set forth in the draft loan agreement. Based on the straight-line method, the average maturity is 
16.75 years, and the maturity premium payable to ADB is 0.20% per year. 
 
  The government will help finance the project and will assume any incremental cost, 
including the foreign exchange and interest variation risks of the ADB loan. ADB will finance 99% 
of the additional financing cost ($16.00 million), and the government will finance $0.16 million for 
project implementation of the additional financing. The financing plan is in Table 2.

E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
  Implementation  arrangements,  such  as  the  steering  committee,  executing  and 
implementing  agencies,  and  the  PIU,  will  remain  unchanged.  The  engaged  construction 
contractor and the construction supervisors under the current project will continue their respective 
roles under the overall project. 
 
  The proposed additional financing will be implemented over 18 months from July 2019 to 
31 December 2020, which is within the closing date of the current project. The implementation 
arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in the PAM.

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
  The current project has ensured international accreditation of the central drug laboratory 
(the first international accredited laboratory in Mongolia) through the implementation of biosafety 
standards level 2 and proper disposal of hazardous chemical waste and the installation of a 
ventilation system separating clean and contaminated air, among others.18 
 
  The construction of the SDH is in line with the latest national and selected international 
standards; and integrates modern patient management concepts, high building functionality, and 
improved  earthquake  resilience  and  fire  safety  standards.  Medical  technology  (imaging, 
laboratory, and sterilization) will take local conditions into account following national guidelines. 
Maintenance services included in the supply contracts and strengthening of maintenance services 
will enhance local capacity to maintain supplied equipment. An international hospital management 
firm  will  provide  technical  assistance  to  the  SDH  after  construction  to  assist  in  hospital 
management, service expansion and integration, human resources development, financing, 
equipment operations and maintenance, and communication and hospital information technology. 
 
B.  Economic and Financial 
 
  The project’s 20-year economic viability was assessed by estimating the economic internal 
rate of return (EIRR) for the establishment of the SDH and was undertaken in accordance with 
                                                
18 Biosafety levels are a series of protections and safeguards against infectious agents designed to protect laboratory 
personnel, as well as the surrounding environment and community.

7 
ADB guidelines.19 The economic analysis incorporates an update of the assessment carried out 
under the current project. The project’s economic benefits include efficiency savings through the 
introduction of new services and improved treatment at the SDH, savings to consumers through 
reduced travel costs to access hospital services, time savings to consumers of health services 
and escorts through reduced travel time to seek health services, and new job opportunities. The 
project will also generate substantial unquantifiable benefits related to improved productivity, 
improved health literacy by educating patients and families, and the creation of job opportunities 
in hospital-related businesses. The EIRR for the current project was estimated as 11.95%. The 
updated EIRR for the overall project is 7.7% and the economic net present value is $5.3 million. 
An EIRR for health projects above 6.0% is considered acceptable when substantial unquantifiable 
benefits are present (footnote 19). The overall project is considered economically viable. A 
sensitivity analysis of potential benefit reductions and a recurrent cost increase indicate that the 
overall project remains economically viable. 
 
  The financial analysis was undertaken following ADB guidelines.20 The analysis focused 
on financial sustainability and evaluated the government’s fiscal capacity to finance counterpart 
funding and incremental recurrent costs after project completion, as the project has no revenue-
generating component. The project is found to be financially sustainable at the project level as 
the funds requirement for the counterpart contribution during the implementation period (2012–
2020) is less than 1% of the health sector annual budget. The recurrent costs of the overall project 
are estimated at $3.32 million per year or 1% of the forecast government health budget. Low 
budget predictability within the sector poses a substantial risk and may result in shortages of funds 
for  operation  and  maintenance  of  the  hospital.  To  ensure  future  project  sustainability,  the 
government  has  agreed  to  provide  assurances  that  operation  and  maintenance  and  other 
required funding are available on a timely basis. The risks and mitigation measures are outlined 
in Table 4. 
 
C.  Governance 
 
  The MOH has been a partner of ADB since 1991. The additional financing includes limited 
procurement activities consisting of direct contracting for the SDH construction and a civil works 
package for the construction of the parking space and the second access road of the hospital site. 
The PIU established for the current project, which is performing satisfactorily, will continue to 
handle all project financial matters, procurement, and recruitment of consultants, supervised by 
the MOH. The contractor for the construction of the SDH works under an International Federation 
of Consulting Engineers (FIDIC) contract with the MOH. Civil works supervision is carried out 
effectively by the design company and the Ulaanbaatar City Investment Department. In addition, 
the MOH has recruited a civil works coordinator to monitor construction progress independently 
and coordinate stakeholders’ activities at the construction site. The PIU staff prepares monthly 
construction works progress reports and provides ADB and the MOH regular updates. The 
updated procurement and financial management capacity assessment concluded that the overall 
project procurement management risk is low and the financial management risk is moderate. The 
executing  agency  has  adequate  capacity  to  comply  with  ADB’s  procurement,  financial 
management, and disbursement policies and guidelines. 
 
  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with  the  government  and  the  MOH.  The  specific  policy  requirements  and  supplementary 
measures are described in the PAM (footnote 17). 
                                                
19 ADB. 2017. Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects. Manila. 
20 ADB. 2005. Financial Management and Analysis of Projects. Manila.

8 
 
D.  Poverty and Social 
 
  Additional financing will enable the completion of the SDH to improve the range and quality 
of hospital services provided to the population. The SDH will directly benefit about 320,000 mostly 
poor residents of Songinohairkhan, a poor and medically underserved district of Ulaanbaatar.21 
The overall project will also benefit the entire population of Mongolia by improving access to safer 
drugs, and, in the long run, will improve allocative efficiency in the health sector by optimizing the 
use of hospital services and improving the return on future investment in hospitals. Poverty and 
health are strongly related, and better health services are not only a social goal but also a 
prerequisite to economic development. Therefore, improved health care will expand the economic 
opportunities of the whole population, including the poor. The summary poverty reduction and 
social strategy was updated to reflect additional financing.22 
 
  The current and overall project are classified effective gender mainstreaming. In Mongolia, 
the health status of the population is highly differentiated by sex. The male mortality rate is high, 
and male life expectancy is low compared with females, primarily because of unhealthy lifestyle 
habits such as smoking and heavy drinking. Women comprise the majority of users and providers 
of Mongolia’s health care system, head 8.7% of all households in the country,23and provide most 
 
care for sick family members. About 80% of the country’s medical staff are women. Most gender 
actions have been completed, but implementation of the gender action plan will be continued.24 
The current project has ensured the participation of at least 50% of women in postgraduate and 
hospital management training, and capacity building and planning activities for drug regulatory 
activities. The overall project will continue to ensure the participation of women in working groups 
and decision-making bodies, identify and address gender-specific needs for hospital services and 
diagnostics, and increase the employment of women in the new SDH. 
 
E.  Safeguards 
 
  In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project’s safeguard 
categories are as follows. 
 
  Environment (category B). The initial environmental examination (IEE)25 of the current 
project was updated following ADB policies and requirements, including the Safeguard Policy 
Statement. The updated IEE addressed the environmental impact of the project modifications, 
including (i) constructing a 40-square-meter (m2) electrical substation and a 49 m2 medical gas 
building within the hospital site to conform with the requirement of the government inspection 
authority and (ii) rerouting the hospital access road. The principal environmental impacts to 
complete the SDH are (i) increased traffic congestion near the project sites, (ii) increased noise 
and dust levels, and (iii) occupational and community health and safety issues. These impacts 
are considered reversible and site specific and can easily be mitigated to acceptable levels 
through sound environmental management planning. The updated IEE concluded that the project 
is unlikely to have significant adverse environment, health, and safety impacts. 
 
                                                
21 An analysis of the hospital bed capacity of the Songinohairkhan district in relation to its population points to an 
important bed shortage. This contrasts with some other districts of Ulaanbaatar that have a bed capacity surplus. 
22 Summary Poverty Reduction and Social Strategy (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
23 National Statistics Office of Mongolia. 2018. Mongolian Statistical Yearbook, 2017. Ulaanbaatar. 
24 Gender Action Plan (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
25 Initial Environmental Examination (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2).

9 
  Environmental management and monitoring plans have been prepared, with budgets and 
responsibilities for implementation assigned. The climate risk for the additional financing is low. 
Contractors will implement these environmental management measures during construction, and 
facility operators and the MOH will implement them during operation. The effectiveness of these 
measures will be regularly evaluated in the framework of the environmental monitoring program, 
and corrective actions will be defined as required. The government is committed to managing the 
identified environmental risks. The updated IEE has been disclosed on the ADB website. 
 
  Involuntary resettlement (category B). The current project was classified category C for 
involuntary resettlement as the SDH is being constructed on existing government land and does 
not require resettling households. The additional financing is classified category B because 
rerouting the hospital access road will have an impact on a limited number of households. Based 
on the census and preliminary inventory of lost assets carried out in March 2019, 16 plots will be 
affected (2,013 m2 of licensed and 1,400 m2 of unlicensed land). Of the 21 households, eight have 
houses or gers (traditional tents) and must relocate. Consultations have been carried out with the 
affected households during resettlement planning and will continue during resettlement plan 
updating and implementation. A land acquisition and resettlement plan has been prepared 
following the ADB Safeguard Policy Statement and Mongolian laws.26 The resettlement plan 
follows the principle of replacement cost; describes the grievance redress mechanism established 
for the project; and includes mitigation measures to address the impacts and risks on the affected 
households, especially the poor and vulnerable households. The government is committed to 
manage resettlement issues and to update and implement the resettlement plan. Copies of the 
resettlement information booklets were distributed to the affected persons and the resettlement 
plan has been disclosed on the ADB website. 
 
  Indigenous peoples (category C). The social analysis and consultations confirmed that 
separate ethnic minorities are not present in the project area of the additional financing project. 
All people will benefit from access to quality hospital services. 
 
F.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
  The overall benefits and impacts are expected to outweigh the costs and risks, and the 
overall risk after mitigation measures is moderate for the overall project. Major risks and mitigating 
measures are summarized in Table 4 and described in detail in the risk assessment and risk 
management plan.27 
 
Table 4: Summary of Risks and Mitigating Measures 
Risks  Mitigating Measures 
Government does not allocate sufficient  Project-generated  O&M  costs  will  be  estimated  before  the 
funds for O&M costs generated by  annual budget preparation, and ADB and the PIU will monitor 
overall project investments and  their inclusion in the MOH budget. A loan covenant to ensure 
activities for hospitals, and drug  sufficient  O&M  funds  for  the  SDH  is  included  in  the  loan 
laboratory and drug regulatory  agreement of the current project. 
improvement measures, because of 
lack of predictable financing. 
Lack of willingness to conform to the  The  current  project  supported  the  regulatory  framework  for 
hospital capital planning system results  capital investment planning, which needs to be reinforced to 
in lack of investment coordination  become more stringent. The regulatory tools need to be better 
enforced. This will require (i) capacity building for relevant MOH

(e.g., regulations for medical  staff and (ii) advocacy at government and parliament, which

ADB = Asian Development Bank, MOH = Ministry of Health, O&M = operation and maintenance, PIU = project 
implementation unit, SDH = Songinohairkhan district hospital. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
IV.  ASSURANCES 
 
  The government and the MOH have assured ADB that implementation of the project shall 
conform to all applicable ADB policies, including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the PAM and loan documents. 
 
  The government and the MOH have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, 
which are set forth in the loan agreement. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of $16,000,000 
to Mongolia for the additional financing of the Fourth Health Sector Development Project, from 
ADB’s ordinary capital resources, in regular terms, with interest to be determined in accordance 
with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility; for a term of 25 years, 
including a grace period of 8 years; and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in 
accordance with those set forth in the draft loan agreement presented to the Board. 
 
Takehiko Nakao 
President 
 
17 June 2019

c  Overall project refers to the current project and the proposed second additional financing. 
d  Including legal, regulatory, and institutional reforms; capacity building needs; and potential financing sources. 
e  Including surgical and maternity services, adequate diagnostic and laboratory capacity, integrated management of 
out- and inpatient departments, model nursing care, proper medical waste management, adequate infection 
prevention and control measures, and advanced information technology tools for patient and financial management. 
f  Based on needs (certificates), minimum number of beds, and services and diagnostic requirements. 
Source: Asian Development Bank.

metadata.Keywords: 41243-024, mongolia health sector, mongolia hospitals, mongolia health care, terms and conditions, board  approval, rrp, approved projects, recommendations of the  president
metadata.Subject: The additional financing will address cost overruns to complete the Songinohairkhan district hospital (SDH)—a new demonstration general hospital in Songinohairkhan, a poor and underserved district in the capital city, Ulaanbaatar.
metadata.Title: Fourth Health Sector Development Project - Additional Financing: Report and Recommendation of the President
